job_title: CLS II in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great co-worker Great Benefit Pay raised due to union
cons: Under staffed Parking price Overwork

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits were good, they offer a lot of support and learning about the benefits available to you
cons: Recommend avoiding working at the Hillcrest location, I was told it’s been deemed irreparable and it was constantly having plumbing issues while I was there. One of the patient rooms had to be closed multiple times because of water coming in from the floor above. Very stressful place to work as well, as most hospitals are

job_title: Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: good benefits, good coworkers, plenty of resources
cons: management unorganized sometimes, work was boring

job_title: MEDICAL CODING MANAGER in San Diego, CA
pros: Great benefits, awesome management team and staff
cons: represented staff and unionized can be challenging

job_title: Attending ER Physician in San Diego, CA
pros: Some great faculty and colleagues.
cons: It operates much like a corporate-owned physician group and not like an academic entity. Very bottom-line driven but with little concern for improving the conditions that make it difficult for a physician to efficiently practice. Being a good doctor or good teacher to residents/med students is not rewarded or even encouraged. Advocating for quality care or patient safety and quality improvement is actively discouraged, much like it is in corporate-owned physician groups.

job_title: Travel Nurse in La Jolla, CA
pros: Good teamwork, I felt like the care we were giving made sense and was evidence based, great patient ratios for nurses, always got a lunch
cons: very strict about time off- need to request far ahead of time and my schedule was very patchy (not a lot of times when i had three shifts in a row)

job_title: Staff Research Associate I in La Jolla, CA
pros: Work hours are very flexible, good medical benefit options, lots of paid holidays.
cons: No parking, have to pay for parking, low salary, unionized, low opportunities for career advancement unless seeking additional degrees.

job_title: Data Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: - Lots of cutting edge research happening in department - Connected to large hospital system - Access to world class research resources
cons: - HR, payroll, medical insurance, etc is a nightmare to work with

review_title: Great working environment, pay could be better
job_title: Applications Developer in San Diego, CA
pros: UCSD Health is a great place to work. Your colleagues will be great people who know their stuff. Most workplaces are flexible on working hours, and remotes work is often possible. The work you do is valuable and appreciated. Benefits are very good.
cons: The pay is below what you could earn in private industry. For software folks, WELL-below. This may make it difficult in San Diego.

job_title: Lab Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great benefits, work is meaningful and good, good culture on a larger scale
cons: Pay is lower than average, if your lab is small you are at the mercy of your lab mates

job_title: Career Coach in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits, Student interactions, cross-functional collaboration
cons: poor upper management, career advancement and lack of professional development

job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Friendly staff and work environment. Good Benefits. Hybrid work schedule.
cons: lack of training. Low salary/hourly wage. Department is always understaffed. The job itself is very boring.

review_title: Although it’s one of the best hospitals in San Diego…
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in San Diego, CA
pros: There is a lot of room for the company to grow, not in size, but maturity. Administration and management should not expect to hold employees accountable for certain things while avoiding their own accountability at all costs.
cons: Employees have to pay for parking and it is pretty normal to get your car broken while you’re working. While false claims about being able to place security cameras in the parking lot are touted, it’s not uncommon to get a ticket if you don’t pay for parking. While ticket trigger happy it doesn’t appear they have any sort of reasonable security protecting their employees vehicles. Who is going catch the ball of responsibility? The university, management, the union? The security team? Nobody wants to be liable and it’s shows. Why has this problem existed for over ten years an has not been addressed? Hard workers don’t like walking to a parking lot with urine scented elevators and stairs only to find their car broken into after working for 12 hours to save a life. I believe we can all do better, but not if we keep ignoring the basic fundamentals of safety.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Opportunity, competitive salary and benefits.
cons: Favoritism, fails to recognize employee value.

review_title: Great place, but bargaining pay is hard
job_title: Staff Research Associate I in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great benefits including healthcare and dental care
cons: Hard to negotiate pay since it's a UC system

job_title: SRAIII in San Diego, CA
pros: good working environment and co-workers
cons: no bonus, few pto, depending on pi fund

job_title: Lead Clinical Research Coordinator in La Jolla, CA
pros: If you're on a good team, collaboration is nice.
cons: Low pay Low benefits Low university transparency Poor administrative systems

job_title: Graduate Student in San Diego, CA
pros: As a graduate student in the Biomedical Sciences program, I have had a great experience in terms of their support and understanding of the graduate student experience when I first arrived. The staff was friendly and attentive to our needs.
cons: As the years have gone by, it seems as those students coming in after were not having the same experience with PI to admin communication, but not in a drastic way. The program is expanding and experiencing some growing pains.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Diego, CA
pros: Good family-like culture, meaningful work
cons: Suitable only if you are really interested in research

job_title: Research Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: it was great experience overall
cons: Not a long term job

job_title: Admin Officer 2 in San Diego, CA
pros: Great health benefits and retirement.
cons: Not a great place for upward movement. Very difficult to get a promotion or pay raise. Hard work is not rewarded. Your pay can not be above a certain “equity percentage” of others in your payroll title.

job_title: Research Associate in La Jolla, CA
pros: benefits, retirement, flexibility, no micromanaging
cons: low pay, no OT, sometimes work weekend, no real training

job_title: Registered Nurse in La Jolla, CA
pros: UC San Diego has good benefits and retirement
cons: UC San Diego is highly political

job_title: Web Author in San Diego, CA
pros: Helpful for professional growth in and out of the workplace.
cons: No cons to disclose for this workplace.

job_title: Health Educator in La Jolla, CA
pros: I loved working with students and alongside campus staff.
cons: The quality of your work-life balance is solely based on who is in charge of the department at the time. I went through several different workflows and expectations due to managerial changes.

job_title: Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Pros include getting to be involved with cutting edge research at a respected institution. The staff and researchers are generally very competent for the most part.
cons: There wasn't much in the way of formalized training beyond the online modules that they provided, which is to say that the training is what you make it. If you are willing to invest in training, you can learn and grow, but the training in my case wasn't as formalized or structured as I had perhaps hoped. Also the pay was fairly minimal, although I'm not sure if that's the case for other staff.

review_title: Good place to grow in your career
job_title: Telemetry Technician in La Jolla, CA
pros: Working in a beautiful location such as La Jolla, Flexible scheduling, educational opportunities, only 16 min drive home, awesome coworkers, management that cares about you and listens to you, and benefits, rate of pay is competitive with the market in San Diego.
cons: Way to expensive to park for employees $60 a month at UCSD Jacobs Medical Ctr. My last job it was free to park and it was in Los Angeles go figure. Say goodbye to some of that competitive pay. Union has had ups and downs in the past but has come out with a contract after not having one for years. Not sure why? On the pro side we did get some good bonuses and retro pay. Other cons frequently short staffed , have to work smarter, and the stress level is more than it should be with a lot more work. Also too much stress leads to unhappy phone conversations and job burnout.

job_title: Senior Clinical Analyst in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great benefits. Lots of holidays.
cons: Non-union so raises are hard to come by.

job_title: Senior Database Administrator in San Diego, CA
pros: stable, good weather, cheap city, nice coast,
cons: paid too low, the management is very mean

job_title: Senior Psychometrist in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits: medical, dental, vision, pension, and more
cons: Bureaucracy. We are all overworked and undervalued

job_title: Assistant Director of Health Information Management in San Diego, CA
pros: UC San Diego is at the cutting edge of technology and a pioneer for healthcare procedures. Most importantly, every staff member is patient-centered, acting with kindness and compassion.
cons: Being a large healthcare facility, sometimes it may take some time to forge strong relationships with areas that could be operating in silos. However, I believe this to be more a common, large enterprise challenge than just UC San Diego Health

job_title: Administrative in La Jolla, CA
pros: Love to pay $10 a day to park on campus. The constantly push use of public transportation.
cons:
First they hired me as PER DIEM so UCSD doesn't have to offer benefits. Note they take out 7.5% of your pay to place into a retirement plan that you can only access once you leave UCSD or retire. Being in a union, they take another 2% of your pay. 

Once you work there a year and over 1000 hours, you can apply for a "career" position. BUT this means that you will be offer LESS hourly pay! I'm talking a 10% decrease in hourly rate! 

If you have a domestic partner on your insurance plan, then you have to pay taxes on the THOUSANDS of dollars that UCSD claims they spent on the benefits for your DP.

They constantly shove racial inclusion down your throat even though the staff is well diverse. They even off training specifically for WHITE employees to make sure you are inclusive.

job_title: Per Diem RN in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Supportive 
Staffed
Ratios appropriate
Pays well
cons: Sometimes a little political when it comes to regulations

job_title: Clinical Assistant Professor in San Diego, CA
pros: academic evnironment is good and supportive
cons: too little pay for time

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in La Jolla, CA
pros: Good working environment and flexible
cons: Pay is not fair when you consider inflation.

job_title: Senior Enterprise Architect in San Diego, CA
pros: Working in an academic medical center, fast paced, helping patients. good benefits for those who've been there for a long time. they are forward looking in terms of technology application.
cons: Digital transformation is very slow in a medical center.

job_title: Emergency Trauma Technician in San Diego, CA
pros: Working in the ER is tough, but the people that work are overall outstanding human being and make working there so much better then it would be other wise.
cons: Working in the county hospital ER is not for everyone and can be a very challenging environment to exist in for any amount of time.

review_title: A bit more room for DEI
job_title: Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits, schedule flexibility, recent fully funded advanced training for Leadership..appreciate the investment in an employee’s desire to add to their knowledge and skillset.
cons: Lack of equal pay male to female in “some” roles not all..I often have asked do people even know that UC appointed it’s first Black President… I am frequently met with they had no idea..Lack of Diversity I have attended meetings and have been the only woman of color in Leadership. We do not truly mirror the community we serve across ALL demographics.

job_title: Associate Professor Medical Physics in San Diego, CA
pros: Overall this is a good place to work
cons: Often staff shortage leads to extra work

job_title: Business Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: Meaningful work for the community. Great work life balance. Some departments allow for hybrid / remote
cons: Hard to get salary increases, only way is to ping pong between new jobs. Yearly 3% increase regardless of work performed (good or bad)

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: Great people to work with
cons: HR process is outdated and it is impossible to get a raise or move up in career growth

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Scientist in San Diego, CA
pros: Pension plan, good starting pay for CLS
cons: Weekends and holidays required, no flexibility in schedule

job_title: Program Evaluation Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Good benefits, flexibility in schedule
cons: Pay is not enough for the cost of living in San Diego

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Great place to make connections
cons: Limited work hours if an undergraduate student

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in La Jolla, CA
pros: Wonderful to work with the physicians and patients on the clinical side
cons: The cto is an absolute mess. Little regard for CRC well being.

job_title: Staff Research Associate I in San Diego, CA
pros: You get pretty door benefits options, you’re part of a prestigious research university, you could potentially get great research experience as a stepping stone to graduate schools.
cons: The quality of mentorship in research positions is a crapshoot. Some PIs will have massive teams of volunteer, undergraduate research assistants that do unpaid labor because that is simply a requirement of the field and these volunteers get no relevant mentorship for their future endeavors. Other PIs have small teams and only take on new members they can truly mentor. Generally, asking the people in the lab straight up what the culture is like won’t yield accurate answers because if they’re still there, they can’t be truthful. There’s an exploitative, moralistic attitude about working more than 40 hours a week, as if being unwilling to work more than 8 hours a day means you’re not as dedicated to your work or as capable and competent. Overall, it has been a demoralizing, disillusioning experience. Can’t speak to all SRA positions but I wouldn’t recommend this job to a friend.

job_title: Transplant Recovery Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Solid group coworkers who care about the program
cons: You have to pay for your own parking

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant III in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible spending accounts legal expense plan
cons: Pay for parking, cap out on pay after certain amount of year

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in San Diego, CA
pros: benefits and always room for growth.
cons: No cons it’s a great place to work.

job_title: Anesthesia Technician in San Diego, CA
pros: good pay, benefits, and lots of different cases. UNION
cons: parking costs roughly $100 a month and not guaranteed a spot close by. UNION

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Health benefits, pension plan, amount of holidays
cons: If the higher ups are narcissists, then there's no hope for you. Expect a miserable time as the system works against you. You'll constantly need to fight, defend and justify every little action you take. The micromanagement can be stifling.

review_title: Good place to work but low salary
job_title: Research Data Analyst I in San Diego, CA
pros:
-Good benefit package (low cost healthcare insurance, free vision and dental)
-Good pension and 401/ 403b plan
-Up to 240 hours of vacation
-Very organized and good training
cons:
-Low salary. You should better negotiate at the beginning before accepting the offer. Otherwise, you might be stuck in a low amount of salary for years
-Promotion is limited

job_title: Hospital Unit Secretary in La Jolla, CA
pros: This company has great benefits

job_title: Policy Analyst in La Jolla, CA
pros:
* Good co-workers
* Good working conditions
* Mostly very knowledgeable managers 
* Office workers have good work/life balance
* Very good benefits & pension
* Do good work and you can stay forever if you choose to
* Plenty of possibilities to move upwards
* Possibility of working in a department with flexible work arrangements
* If you have a good boss, you will enjoy the experience
cons:
* Politics really reigns here. It is all around and not something you can get away from.
* If you have a bad boss, your life can be hell
* Pay for parking $96 per month
* Things move slowly here - including hiring new staff
* Sometimes there isn't enough money to get the extra staff needed
* While there are many jobs that open up, there are just as many staff vying for them - sometimes it is very hard to get an interview

job_title: Contact Center Specialist in San Diego, CA

review_title: Amazing place for experience and growth

You can gain a lot of clinical experience 
A lot of chance for personal growth and mentorship with supervisors

Could be either very busy or very boring depending on your volunteer shift.

review_title: Your co-workers will be amazing people, the system itself is just so broken
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Healthcare that gives you access to some of the top doctors around the nation, beautiful work environment, lots of coffee carts, flexible hours
cons: Disorganized bureaucracy, tons of hoops when it comes to getting your paycheck, parking is absolutely appalling because employees don't have parking even if they pay for it and have to compete with professors and students at the school, most of the administration are out of touch and have no idea what's going on so when you call to ask about your paycheck or business account, they put you through five other people. Also, if you've worked for them for a long time, sometimes they'll forget about you and deactivate your business account. Other times, when you need to renew a badge for access to your work building, they'll send you over to Hillcrest from La Jolla to waste your entire unpaid day there to sit through a card orientation that you don't need nor want. They make access to key facilities and administrative items so difficult that it's almost as if they don't want us to work there.

job_title: Lab Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Proper training for lab safety.
cons: Can get confusing of who to report to

job_title: Registered Nurse
pros: Staff is all really helpful and friendly
cons:
Management sits in office behind a closed door all day while RNs are running around short staffed in OR.  I was there for 6 weeks, it was awful.  They don't follow standard OR guidelines and protocols.  They don't follow their own policies.  Patient safety is at risk and being jeopardized.  I quit because it's not a safe place to work, I would not send my worst nightmare here for surgery... especially in July when new residents are left on their own to run the show.  TERRIFYING! No amount of money or great retirement would keep me here, I am a nurse, with patient safety and care being my #1 priority.  Wrong site procedures, dirty instruments, no consents for surgery, Interviewing/confirming surgeries with sedated patients... the list goes on, and I was there for 6 weeks only!!!!!!

Every time I spoke to management I was told "But this is a teaching facility, it's just the way it is"----GO to Scripps... Stay away from this place unless you're ok with jeopardizing care of patients and your license.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Denver, CO
pros: Great to be employed by.
cons: I have no cons to say about this employer

review_title: Work is rewarding but culture is oppressive
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: When allowed to do your job (depending on your department and who you report to), the work is very rewarding.  There is job security in some areas.
cons: There is expectation to work long hours and weekends without compensation and very little recognition for employees or middle management. Director takes credit for department achievements and shows favoritism to one or two people who agree with them no matter what. If you disagree with them, you can expect the silent treatment and increased criticism and scrutiny. Classic bullying. The new CEO will hopefully drive change in the company culture. For now, bullies in upper management are tolerated and promoted no matter how negatively they impact morale and productivity or how little they contribute to success. Pay is low compared to positions in the community with fewer perquisites than private employers. If you are not part of a union, don't expect pay increases.  You can request an equity review but your director may intervene to downgrade or decline the recommendations of Human Resources.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Big organization and they are moving IT forward fairly quickly.
cons: Very poor management at the Manager and Director level. Pay scales are varied and end up being arbitrary. The organization is trying to improve but there are so many people in the organization that have been there for too long or who have been there just long enough that they aren't planning on going anywhere. These individuals know how to work the system and work hard to insulate themselves by building and protecting silos.

job_title: Clinical RN II in San Diego, CA
pros: They offer great benefits to employees. The unit is often times understaffed and no resource nurse to help out. Most days there is pressure to admit, discharge as soon as possible, and keep on going. I became a nurse to nurse and advocate, most days I am rushed and feel I have not done 100% for my patients. Overall, UCSD is a good place to work. The teaching environment is awesome. A lot of times the doctors rely on us nurses and give us independence and autonomy to care for our patients.
cons: The management is very heavy here.... they are worried about incidental overtime and write people up lwft and right for clocking in early, clocking out late.

job_title: SRAII in La Jolla, CA
pros: There are a lot of MD/PhD's doing research, and you will get a behind the scene look at how physician scientists work to translate laboratory science into drugs and treatments. You will also get exposure to and gain knowledge in topics in translational and clinical biomedical research from weekly seminars and talks from visiting scientists. The Center recently acquired a few big shots in the field of personalized medicine and angiogenesis. It is poised to further the science and ambitious about improving outcome for patients.
cons: As an SRA in most, if not all, academic institutes in the life sciences, your pay will increase incrementally over time and with years of experience but no career development/advancement to speak of unless you have a PhD. Research is very result and goal oriented, some not necessarily the most sophisticated, cutting edge, and exploratory science. Logistics and infrastructure is not always the greatest because of bureaucracy. I have seen better research support from facility or core at some other research institutes.

review_title: UC San Diego Health System Per Diem vs. UCSD Permanent Full Time staff
job_title: Hillcrest SAN Diego Hospital and La Jolla Thornton in San Diego, CA
pros: UC San Diego Health System has a large pool of jobs specifically for Per Diem employees at less than 100% rate. The College Educational side and its staff are better than the Hospital Business side. Thornton La Jolla Hospital it has a better atmosphere than Hillcrest; since, it has many other UCSD Facilities and the Main Campus near by.
cons: As a Per Diem UCSD can let you go any time and usually right before you reach your 750 hours; otherwise they are obligated to hired you Full Time Permanent as per Union Regulations. Hence, UC San Diego Health System will avoid paying for Medical Benefits or contributions towards employee retirement (401K, etc.). Some departments might have very young supervisors with not enough experience towards older employees.

job_title: Project Coordinator in La Jolla, CA
pros: Has good benefit depending on when you were hired. Some positions have unions, but still, the unions find hard to for with the strong legal counsel they have. Salaries have shrunk and they pass the benefit cost to the employees year by year.
cons:
Upper mobility is very difficult here, especially for the different culture. They talk a lot about diversity but it is only talking. It is a reactionary system in where the employees dont have a win. 
Salaries have shrunk and they pass the benefit cost to the employees year by year.  Expect to take home 60% of your salary, the rest goes for benefits; medical insurance, pension, etc.

review_title: Great place to work - once upon a time...
job_title: Clinical RN II in San Diego, CA
pros: Work-life balance possible depending on the "needs of the unit" and favoritism. Benefits are among the best I have reviewed in healthcare. Specifically, rate of pay superior to most other hospitals in San Diego, multiple health plan to choose from (although the size is reducing), short and long term disability available, employer paid dental and vision benefits and pension available to career staff. However, employee contribution (for nurses at least) has increased significantly with the last union contract (averaging $200 per pay period) which has led to a significant pay cut in reality.
cons: Very negative nursing management, creating a hostile work environment. Team work not valued. High staff turn over.

job_title: SRA in La Jolla, CA
pros: Medical operation is good and awesome. Many slacker coworkers/managers who does almost nothing at the office still have a job and get yearly raise like everyone else. Good for retiree or the people looking for a very secure job. No performance management system, no employees are being fired for poor performance.
cons: Low salary (around 40%-50% lower than industry). Able and experienced people need to do more work to "support" inexperienced and green people (some people are manager relatives). The supporting tasks go by unnoticed and unappreciated until some quality issues raised, and they put your supporting job on the line. Working from home is not allowed (except for some people, very unfair). No chance of moving up or get raises even if your education, skills, or experience go above the job required, no matter how lazy or how hard you work. Many managers stay here to retire, therefore, the concept or management skill for clinical trial stays 20 years ago.

job_title: Assistant III in La Jolla, CA
pros: There's lots of career development, very nurturing and supportive senior leaders, great benefits, flex-time, great co-workers & working environment, and plenty of fun and challenging projects. Most of the senior leaders are very open to new ideas and value the input of young professionals, which makes you feel like your opinions matter. Others may have different opinions and views, but I guess it just depends on the department/unit one works in. As a young professional, I'd definitely say that it's a great place for other young professionals to consider when looking for jobs.
cons: Parking at the University in general is expensive and extremely limited and the facilities aren't  all "super cool," but it's not bad.

review_title: Working in nutrition services seemed to be promising at first but turned out to be a really frustrating experience.
job_title: Nutrition Department in La Jolla, CA
pros: Good benefits. Considerably high pay for food services as compared to other hospitals. Maybe half of other staff are pleasant to work with. Lovely place to work in La Jolla.
cons: Extremely poor management, does very little to help team unlike every job I've ever had. RARE getting time off approved because constantly short staffed. High turnover rates, I can say I've seen 50-75% of old or new staff leave since I've been here and they aren't replaced on time. UNFAIR distribution of work. NO ROOM FOR GROWTH. TERRIBLE parking, $81/month which is increasing AND barely any parking at all!

job_title: Clinical Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Pay, benefits, proximity to home
cons: No teamwork, unsafe, unsupportive administration, whistleblowers get squeezed out in a well-orchestrated campaign of making your life hell as long as you continue to work there.

review_title: Great Benefits but Two Divisions to Avoid
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Diego, CA
pros: The benefits are incomparable.  The best I've seen anywhere.  You pay next to nothing for medical, dental and vision. They also give you free legal assistance and more.
cons:
Internal people to UCSD know that two divisions that you don't want to go to are Cancer Research and Pediatrics.  They have high turnover and are not managed well.
Internal systems are cumbersome, causing it to take a long time to get simple things done.

Certain people seem to be favored.  Not all employees are treated with respect. An environment where many people talk about each other behind their backs.

review_title: UCSD, great benefits if you can stand the apartheid between filipinos and americans.
job_title: OR Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Programs and opportunities to support oneself with self improvement whether it be through degreed programs or continuing education. UCSD offers phenomenal retirement benefits that keep it's employees focused on their future.
cons: Upper management is ran by all Filipino nurses that show favoritism toward people of the same cultural background instead of rewarding the "other" employees that work hard. There is a clear segregation that makes it uncomfortable for workers like myself from a different culture. It does not help that upper management along with my own peers speak in tagalog even during meetings. It needs to stop.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros:
good benefits - new employees get 3 weeks of vacation per year, good retirement benefits
Great place to work for clinical research
Location is awesome, but very expensive
cons:
HR department does not know anything and they are not helpful. Almost all jobs are covered by the union and they don't tell you until after you are hired. Union dues are automatically taken out of your paycheck and you can't withdraw from the union. My salary was capped because of a union equity policy. When you call HR, they never know if certain policies apply to you so you can't get answers. 
Transportation to campus is awful

review_title: They will drive you to your mental and physical limits while barely making a salary above the poverty line.
job_title: Lab Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Good health benefits, notable research facility
cons: They will underpay you and not care. I am an HIV researcher doing the work of multiple people, doing projects far outside and above my job description. No compensation and no title change despite multiple meetings with supervisors. I barely make ends meet every month. The shuttle driver that takes me to work in the morning makes more money than I do, and the person who works the coffee cart next door makes the same pay. Never work here. You will be driven to your mental and physical limits while barely making above the poverty line.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: Name brand recognition, legacy of great science, great location.
cons: Leadership with few exceptions that are business people trying to manage a healthcare organization without the slightest clue about the delivery of actual care (from either the standpoint of a patient or provider), poor morale, and mediocre care.

job_title: Research Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: You can have little to no experience and get hired because the turnover rate is so high.
cons: They do not give you raises and put you in low paying job titles that are not reflective of what you do - making you grossly underpaid. The workload is astronomically unreasonable and you will not be compensated for it. You will be reprimanded for not finishing it. You will be paid little to nothing and be charged 81 a month for parking. When your union is out of contract they will increase your healthcare coverage cost to $300. You will not have the tools to do your job. If you offer suggestions on how to fix your work place issues they will be ignored. You will be beaten down until you quit and a new employee will come in and get paid the bare minimum.

job_title: Applications Developer in La Jolla, CA
pros: Easygoing, low stress environment. Nice, clean campus. Good pension.
cons:
Lack of challenging work. Management afraid of new technology... managing data with excel spreadsheets, no electronic signature. Not allowed to work from home so no relief from terrible open office, limited, and expensive staff parking, and difficult SD commutes. Organizational lip service to trends like ‘diversity’ and ‘collaboration’ but no real interest in employee satisfaction or hiring skilled people.
Low pay and benefit erosion they refuse to acknowledge.

review_title: UCSD Nursing - Great Benefits, Good Compensation, Challenging Work Environment
job_title: Critical Care, Clinical RN II in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
You are part of the UC system, which allows you to transfer between campuses without losing any of your seniority and most of your benefits are the same wherever you go.  You work for the only university-hospital in San Diego, which can be a blessing or a curse depending on your personal feelings.  UCSD Healthcare and the School of Medicine are in the top 10 in NIH funding nationally, so you are always exposed to the latest research and findings.

It has excellent benefits, Dental and Vision are provided free of charge to full-time employees, and medical, legal AD&D, life, short-term and long-term disability are provided at affordable costs.  Benefits are on a sliding scale so that the more employees make the more they contribute to medical costs, therefore employees making less have less of a cost.  They have an excellent retirement program, includes a mandatory contribution program and a 403(b), 457 voluntary contribution program.  One of the most attractive benefits is the UCRP (Pension Plan), which new employees become vested in five years.  

Communication between senior management and employees is well communicated through email and other media around the two campuses.
cons:
The primary downside of working at UCSD is that it lacks a collaborative environment.  The system is governed by the kingdom philosophy on management, where one person makes the decision that affects everyone else.  UCSD has announced a journey to Magnet in orientation, but that's the last I ever heard about it.  Senior management places significantly more emphasis on physician input than in implementation of policy.  This is contrary to the Magnet journey that is being embraced by leadership.  Management runs healthcare like a business, always concerned about cost, which I acknowledge is an important factor is running a business, but sacrifices patient safety at times, through strict staffing, lack of a primary nursing model and continuity of care.  Labor disputes are common every couple of years while a contract is being negotiated.  They have a labor union for every group of employee, which again can be positive or negative depending on your own perspective.  Work environment can be unit and department specific.  There are units that are great places to work and have excellent management, however there are units that have hostile work environments and have poor managements as well.

Nursing leadership at UCSD is small, weak, poorly structured, and easily influenced by the business management within the leadership team.  This results in business decisions being implemented that doesn't necessarily benefit patient care and is often directed at taken the cost out of the business, often at the expense of patient safety.  Positive feedback is sometimes used, however negative job performance is always communicated.  Nursing leadership is frequently concerned with the bottom line; often they are not supportive of staff.  One of the corporate philosophies at UCSD is service, and frequently obsessed with patient satisfaction.  They are willing to bend over backwards to accommodate this often at the expense of there own employees.  In dealing with errors in the system, they place emphasis on individual punitive disciplinary action versus investigating the root cause analysis of mistakes or errors.

Furthering your education is mentioned in orientation, but the reality of the situation is that there is no education reimbursement or incentive program to continue your education.  The only education benefit is you receive 30% off tuition at UCSD, which lacks a School of Nursing.  Furthermore, you can't use the program in UCSD Extensions, which is the continuing education arm at UCSD, and in concurrent enrollment, which allows you to take courses without matriculating to the university.  The only way to qualify for reduced tuition is to be enrolled in a degree program.

review_title: Overall, would be excited work for UC San Diego Health again
job_title: Staff Research Associate in Beijing, Beijing
pros:
Work environment: Excellent overall in both research and clinical setting. Felt accepted, valued, and that it was a positive workplace.

Career opportunities: While I didn't utilize my education benefits I was aware that there were numerous opportunities.

Compensation & Benefits: I felt well taken care of in both benefits and compensation

Work/Life Balance: Well balanced. Team was understanding and supportive.

Senior Management: Any issues were promptly taken care of and upper management was even pro-active.

Culture & Values: UCSD believes in their mission statement and values.
cons:
Parking permit: Working at UC San Diego Health I paid for a parking permit, which for a Staff member was $81.00 a month.

Location: San Diego has increasingly become an expensive place to live.

review_title: I would NOT receive my healthcare from Thornton Hospital and I work there!
job_title: Nurse in Beijing, Beijing
pros: Benefits and retirement are the only good reasons to stay at Thornton Hospital.
cons: Management has no idea about conflict resolution and the training process is based on whether or not you fit into the clique that management is in. There is blatant favoritism among the filipinos and because of that, there is a high turnover rate. Management does not respect it's employees and don't listen to how to solve problems from the employees. Instead, the problems just keep resurfacing and nothing is done about them. Thornton Hospital is the most frustrating place I have ever worked and I am looking to change jobs as soon as possible.

review_title: Excellent benefits from a progressive and generous employer
job_title: in Avila
pros:
Pay is significantly higher than that offered by other employers
13 paid holidays per year
10 hours of vacation earned each month (for FT employees)
8 hours of sick time earned each month (for FT employees)
Very good health, pharmacy, and dental benefits
cons:
Complex hierarchy of management - the beaurocracy can make it difficult to communicate concerns to management. Even if concerns are stated, it is difficult to determine whose job it is to address them.

Union dues are deducted from each paycheck, regardless of the employee's wishes.

AFSCME (the union to which most employees belong) has a strong influence on the center's policies. Many of these policies protect employees who don't pull their weight.

review_title: Avoid Department of Department of Emergency Medicine Office
job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits (medical, dental and vision), HSA, retirement and employee discounts. Overall the University of California is a progressive research-based system with talented medical staff and researchers.
cons: Unfortunately each UC system is different and San Diego struggles. Morale is low across the board. Consistency in mission, professionalism and high turnover are a few of their downfalls. Steer clear of the clerical branch of the Department of Emergency Medicine. Managed by unprofessional and unethical managers (happen to be family members). HIGH turnover speaks for itself.

review_title: Pay Discrepancies, Understaffed, and Poor Management
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: The benefits are decent. Amazing staff and some of the coolest people I've met over the years. Good work experience.
cons: People are leaving in droves. No contracts being made with the unions, no pay raises for over two years, no cost of living increases, and serious pay inequities across the board. Our team has almost vanished, no new members have been hired, and the work keeps piling up. Management apparently does not listen to its own staff and our HR Department is a complete joke.

review_title: An honest look at whats going on with this hospital...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits/PTO/Friendly work environment/La Jolla campus is beautiful (although hillcrest is a dump)
cons: No communication, lack of movement in policies (a lot of talk, very little action), terrible resources as an employee

job_title: Phlebotomist in San Diego, CA
pros: great overall benefits,pay,401,retirement . all the benefits are great here the best employer I have ever workerd for. I will retirer here for sure. you must apply
cons: parking is a big con. you have to pay monthly for your parking. and if you get a ticket its a lot of money. I don't think we should be paying to parking. I have never had an employer where I have to pay to park my car.

review_title: Overall it was a very pleasant experience.
job_title: Patient Service Representative in San Diego, CA
pros: The environment is upbeat. Lots of team spirit. Every month there is some activity that you have the option to attend. Benefits are excellent. Management looks out for the team.
cons: Being glued to a phone. If you don't like a desk job, where you have to be stuck there. Then customer service for patient revenue is out. Retirement mandatory 9% deducted biweekly could be good or bad depending on your stance. Office full of woman can have its moments of drama.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: Boss was very transparent about how systems worked, let me have flexibility for hours, gave a lot of freedom for me to make decisions about how things were run
cons: Pay was not as high as other places, uncertain of how to advance to the next level, no bonuses or good benefits. Parking was horrible, very expensive to have that benefit

review_title: Was good...until new management came in
job_title: IT Technician in San Diego, CA
pros: It was great as a studnet IT tech.  You had your own office, you worked pretty much independently or with fellow techs with minimal supervision; it was a pretty low key job.
cons: Fixing mundane computer problems or user problems can be a drag at times, but those folks there like most of the older generation aren't too computer savvy, so it's understandable.  It's my understanding that techs there have lost a lot of flexibility and autonomy though, so now it's not such a great place to work anymore.

review_title: Very engaging workplace with challenging tasks
job_title: Programmer Analyst in La Jolla, CA
pros: Very nice working atmosphere with very friendly employees and supervisors. Everyone is very understanding and are very helpful. The software projects are not too difficult but can give a challenge to unfamiliar programmers. There are also other projects that involves non-programming skills.
cons: You will need to be motivated in order to put out good work. You will need to be assertive to get new tasks and new projects to work on.

job_title: Radiology Technologist in San Diego, CA
pros: We have a lot of freedom to do the job how we see fit.  Sometims any way.  sometimes we get micromanaged by people who think they're smart but really are not.
cons: Dr's nurses and administrators treat you like scum bag.  There is no professional development or feedback, or training

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: The Senior Management is avery good group to work with. My direct reports is great and treats me extremely well. Not a micro-manager, encourages growth and risk taking.
cons: C- Suite Leadership has been in a fairly constant state of flux. People leave for good things, but it clearly creates challenges regarding continuity of direction and expectation.  Directors and managers have too few incentives.

job_title: Project Manager in La Jolla, CA
pros: Good benefits, reasonably good facilities
cons: Extreme micromanagement, culture of fear to act on anything - whether clinical or administrative, organization wastes tons of money and man-hours.

job_title: Admin Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros:
- Lots of people to connect with
- Get a good medical background
- Great experience as a student
- Medical Center Badge
cons:
- Busy work (esp. as student)
- Sometimes it's a hectic environment to try and seek support from superiors so you have to take advantage of opportunities

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in La Jolla, CA
pros: The science is great. The connection to patients is great.
cons: The organization of the whole building is terrible. There is no way to email to labs to borrow reagents in a pinch or get a cell line. The lab I ended up in was poorly managed and the worst lab I've ever worked in.  Lab members were hostile to each other, aggressively competitive, and even resorted to sabotage. There are barely any seminars. You have to pay for a parking permit.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits are great!  Vacation and sick time is very generous.  San Diego is a beautiful place to work and live. I've met a lot of really nice folks throughout the organization.
cons: Culture is difficult and challenging.  Some people in higher level positions are not qualified demonstrated by work or lack of.  Staff recognition outside my department doesn't exist.

review_title: Full of talented people and amazing learning experiences.
job_title: Human Resources Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Great learning environment for undergrad students looking to explore areas of interest
- Flexible! They work with you and your school schedule and change your hours on a quarterly basis if necessary
- Approach-ability = you get a lot of opportunities to meet very high-level professionals, and they are very easy to talk to! Great networking opportunities here.
cons: - very large organization, so if your work is very specialized and you may not see your immediate impact within the organization

job_title: COMMUNITY HEALTH REPRESENTATIVE in San Diego, CA
pros: San Diego is a great city to work in and the benefits that UCSD offer are very difficult to find with other employers. The medical, dental and retirement options are affordable and comprehensive. The work environment is educational, comfortable and progressive. A very rewarding career can be found at UCSD Health.
cons: The UCSD Health System can be complicated and require training. It is best to know what is expected of you as an employee before you accept a position and know what you are expecting from the company.

review_title: Just got hired so not much to say yet
job_title: Clinical Nurse II in San Diego, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, competitive pay, managers are super nice, areas to move up/grow, supportive work environment, plenty of staff to help
cons: Just started so hard to tell yet. One thing is that everything is based on seniority so it takes a while for raises, moving up, switching to day shift, etc. Have some older, grumpy bully type nurses due to their great pension plan they always stay a long time.

review_title: Great place to work with some areas for improvement
job_title: Lab Technician in San Diego, CA
pros: Campus is gorgeous, people tend to be nice. I think it depends on your boss, but it is a great place that overall looks out for its employees
cons: UCSD tends to put up a fight when negotiating with unions. Also, their great retirement account may be on its way out as they've started promoting a different plan that ends up being less valuable.

job_title: Clinical Nurse II in San Diego, CA
pros: Love that I work in a supportive environment with what I feel is a mostly fair workload with the resources I need to provide safe and high quality patient care.
cons: Upper management feels inaccessible and seems to be out of touch at times with the reality of providing care in today's world. It seems profits are prioritized over what's best for the staff and the patients.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: People are great.  Most stable employment I've had in years.  Most are a joy to work with.
cons: Listened to about a 5 minute ramble of stereotypes about former military from my boss.  Not an upwardly mobile institution.  Advancement is by getting a different job, and probably a different manager.

job_title: CLS, Senior Supervisor in La Jolla, CA
pros: UC San Diego Health is the best hospital system in which to work in the San Diego area!  The benefits are phenomenal, the pay is very competitive, and the atmosphere is very positive and uplifting.  I have been at UC San Diego Health for almost 7 years and this is definitely the best hospital for which I have worked!!  I love coming to work everyday!
cons: Parking is a bit pricey and it's difficult to find parking spots.

job_title: in La Jolla, CA
pros: The best reason to work here is that it is a fun and stable job. The people are friendly and the city is calm.
cons: The hours of operation are rather taxing. There are a lot of times where you are left with a lot of work on your plate and no one will help you

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Diego, CA
pros: UC San Diego Health has a ton of awards, accolades, and recognition throughout the San Diego Community. I'm proud to be a part of meetings where I'm able to listen to stories of our doctors changing lives.  We also have great benefits and an impressive retirement plan.
cons: Due to University of California policies, it's difficult to make any big changes in a short amount of time.  Parking can be tricky and is expensive.

job_title: Information Systems Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits are generous compared to other healthcare institutions in the area. Retirement plan offers 403B and 457B which means you can save twice as much as at most other employees.
cons: Management can be very disorganized, depending on which team you're on.  If you're on IT or business support, be prepared to be on call every once in a while.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: One of the best reason to work for an educational research facility is that your working for a greater cause.  It is always a pleasure to help people.
cons: The process of getting promotion is very long and lengthy process. It seems that a lot of processess is very slow and inefficient.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Diego, CA
pros: I have been working at UCSD Health for 1 year and it is a great place to work. The benefits, and paid holidays/PTO are great. My colleagues and management is also great. They always have an open door and make themselves available when needed. They show concern in the professional development of the team. The hospital is also taking great strides in improving the patient care experience.
cons: Paying for parking. Parking lot gets full.

job_title: Staff Research Associate I in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great benefits, exciting, dynamic work environment, union representation, a tremendous variety of employment options.
cons: Low pay in staff research positions, no promotions, staff treated in these respects like they are expendible, research positions are vey competitive.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: There are multiple labs in the Cancer Center, and the people are all very helping and nice, even if you are not part of their lab. My lab often works with other labs on projects, and there is often sharing of lab equipment among labs
cons: food sucks... have to take the 201 to get there from UCSD

job_title: Programmer Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: Grant based study. Deadline is quite relaxed and not so much pressure from work.
cons:
The pay is really low. No Bonus. I was told the yearly increase of salary is at most 5% which barely covers the inflation. 

Working at a study as a programmer, there is no room to grow since it is mainly for researches. All I (you) do is just helping RA's and researchers transporting data from one to another place.

review_title: Great place to work! Lots of opportunity!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Great ability to work on a lot of different types of projects. Job growth available in all areas. Management really listens to input from all levels of employees.
cons: Parking is always an issue but space is limited so it is understandable.

review_title: Great environment run by overcompensated, terrible leadership and bureaucracy
job_title: Clinical Coordinator in La Jolla, CA
pros: Friendly employees, good benefits, interesting work environment where you learn a lot
cons: Low pay, overworked, poor morale, non-existent leadership, very political "top heavy" organization, management does not support its staff or empower them; no advancement and no pay increases - ever.

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Good pay and benefits. Teaching hospital.
cons: Nurse Managers are unethical,  toxic, bullies. Starts at the top with the Chief Nursing Officer (CNO) !

review_title: Excellent benefits and coworkers; cheap but mostly-friendly management
job_title: Clinical Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Coworkers, benefits, vacation/sick, education leave, education opportunities. Most immediate managers (nursing unit managers) are friendly, responsive, and caring.
cons: Clueless upper management with no grasp of real nursing floor life;   Staff must float inter-facility (between San Diego and La Jolla), not just inter-unit.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Diego, CA
pros: There are great employee benefits and some of the best safety training for scientific lab work.
cons: Your success is highly dependent on who your mentor/advisor is and there are very few checks and balances for poor managers

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Great welcoming environment for junior researchers just starting on their journey. Senior scientists and doctors are willing to give you time, hear out your ideas and provide feedback where needed. Multiple weekly seminars that provide great opportunity to learn about new fields or deepen existing knowledge.
cons: Poor options for food and poor accessibility.

job_title: Senior Technical Project Manager in La Jolla, CA
pros: Best health organization to work for, challenging but very warm atmosphere.
cons: Any change brings huge challenges, as most of the employees have been there very long and it's not easy to bring any good change.

review_title: Progressive academic Hospital with quality patient care
job_title: Staff Registered Respiratory Therapist in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits are good,   Insurance  includes Health, Vision, Dental, Legal  including a Pension  for staff employees.
cons: Parking is expensive ,   RN Salaries should be in line with the other UC Hospitals in California. UCSD is the lowest paying of the Hospitals

review_title: A great place to work with amazing people and opportunity for learning.
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: Great people in high places. Positive attitudes. Good benefit package, along with retirement. Management helps you reach your goals.
cons: Very difficult to be hired. Can be political at times, but that how things are in general.

job_title: Clinical RN II in La Jolla, CA
pros: Teaching hospital, professional and good opportunities for training and advancement. Very hard to get in but easy to move laterally in company. Safe place to work. Can be strict and conservative which is good.
cons: Parking is expensive! Also management is hit or miss, some are good, others have poor management skills.

job_title: Unit Secretary in San Diego, CA
pros: Good health and retirement benefits. Competitive pay.
cons: Employee satisfaction is the least of Managements concern. Staff morale is low. There is no improvement in the current department process to expedite patient care.

job_title: Marketing/Communications in San Diego, CA
pros: Great workplace and culture. People are ver easy to work with and are very willing to help you with completings tasks and your overall success.
cons: Sometimes there aren't enought tasks to do. Could be more engaging and have more challenging tasks.

job_title: Administrative Officer II in San Diego, CA
pros: Job security, good benefits, retirement plan if you stick around.
cons: EVERYTHING is layered in red tape, even the easiest requests or transactions. Feels impossible to track down the right person or get the help needed. Limited room for advancement within one department, you have to move around to where openings are.

job_title: Professor of Medicine in San Diego, CA
pros:
Strong faculty from diverse backgrounds
Good EMR system
In close proximity to UCSD main campus and surrounding research community
cons:
poor leadership and management at all levels
pay structure for physicians is not transparent or equitable
lack of emphasis on research and being a true academic center--greater concern on financial matters, which are kept murky

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in San Diego, CA
pros: Excellent location no matter where you live. Great hospital and services, friendly co-workers. Ok food, pack your meals if you work PM's or Nights.
cons: Parking means high priced and not much security.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros:
Workload is manageable during the scheduled work day.
Holiday, Sick, and vacation is generous
Enjoyable group of people dedicated to one common goal
cons: Progress can be slow moving.  If you see an opportunity for improvement, it often takes some time to create the momentum toward change.

review_title: It doesn't get much better than this
job_title: Programmer Analyst II in San Diego, CA
pros: Great place to work at.  It's a state job with excellent benefits (medical, free dental and vision), an excellent Retirement package (403b and UCRP), great colleagues, and a CEO that cares about his employees.
cons: None that I know of.

review_title: Great Salary and benefits, terrible management
job_title: Endoscopy Technician in San Diego, CA
pros: Great Salary and benefits, great learning experience. Yearly salary increase with good union.
cons: Terrible management, obvious favoritism some Dr.’s have bad attitudes/ habits. Reduction of hours during slow days and no growth opportunities.

job_title: Resident Physician in San Diego, CA
pros: Good location, great coworkers, overall great city to live in, breadth of resources and specialities within the hospital, management overall somewhat responsive to feedback
cons: Long hours as a resident, old facilities in Hillcrest, unhealthy food in cafeteria, limited hours and food selection in cafeteria, challenging parking

review_title: Decent place, just very slow and not always focused
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in La Jolla, CA
pros: Laid back work environment with very little stress.
cons: Too relaxed atmosphere.  Science is supposed to be stimulating and exciting.  Results should be celebrated more.

review_title: Okay if you don't care about a collaborative work environment
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Diego, CA
pros: Nice building with generally good infrastructure
cons: Very uncollaborative. Hardly any interaction between different groups from different floors or even on the same floor

job_title: Provider in San Diego, CA
pros: Frontier academic medicine with unlimited resource of knowledge database.
cons: Large percentage of work is paperwork related, not necessarily direct patient care

job_title: Graduate Peer Educator in San Diego, CA
pros: I loved being able to work with the people at the Career Center who are all amazing and wonderful people. They were very flexible with my class schedule.
cons: Need to keep a 3.0 GPA to work due to graduate division requirements

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Great comraderie among doctors, nursing staff, administration; down-to-earth setting; teaching environment, and humble ways for improvement, pension plan
cons: Cost for employee parking, union fees make salary comparable

job_title: CN II in San Diego, CA
pros: Work/life balance in terms of vacation and comp time; great pension benefits, free dental premiums; autonomy within nursing practice and encouragement and use of best practice through research.
cons: Understaffing, lack of CNAs; "who you know" advancement

review_title: Good Benefits, Lack of good management
job_title: Technologist II, Central Service in La Jolla, CA
pros: great benefits, good compensation time, good vacation time, good sick time
cons: management often overlooks entry level employees, not enough employees, overworked and underpaid

job_title: Postdoctoral Scientist in La Jolla, CA
pros:
exciting environment
plenty of resources to develop good science
good relation between people of your same level
easy access to information.
cons: low management skills from the boss and senior scientists making the process and discovers slower than some other places and universities.

review_title: Great culture and people, little room for career advancement
job_title: Bioinformatics Software Developer in La Jolla, CA

- Flexible work hours
- Amazing people, stimulating environment. Pretty much everyone I worked with is highly skilled and knowledgeable
- Great for research
cons: - Not too many opportunities for growth

review_title: Great place to work and grow.
job_title: Medical Assistant II in San Diego, CA
pros: They pay the best and the doctors are great to work with.
cons: Paying for parking is not unheard of but it is very expensive here. Yes, for employees too. $80 per month for unlimited pass.

review_title: Former Volunteer at hillcrest UCSD hospital
job_title: in San Diego, CA

job_title: Security Agent in San Diego, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA

cons: Some departments follow the rules when it suits them & when they want to do something that suits them, they break policy... Never know where you stand.

review_title: work is steady, secure and challenging

pros: Great benefits, retirement, PTO, holidays, super affordable health insurance/dental

job_title: Medical Assistant in San Diego, CA

job_title: in San Diego, CA

review_title: A great place to work at
